moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6:
Philidor's Defense. 
This move isn't exactly bad, but I don't recommend it unless you know exactly what you're doing. Black would be better off defending the pawn while developing a piece (…Nc6, …Nf6).
moves.3. h3: ? Way too slow. White also should be developing his pieces.
moves.3... c5: !? Interesting. This grabs a big share of the center, but again I think Black would be better off developing pieces.
moves.4. c3: ! A good plan: preparing to blow the center open.
moves.4... Bd7: ?! Black now develops a piece, but not the right one or to the right square. …Nf6 would be more to the point: it gets Black one step closer to castling and attacks the e-pawn. Also, the LSB (Light-Squared Bishop) is better placed on e6, not d7. Development is good, but should be planned out and not done randomly.
moves.5. d4: ! Again, White has exactly the right idea: to open the center and then punish Black's slow development. White's pieces will be able to develop rapidly once the Black pawns are weakened.
moves.5... Nc6: Good, now Black is catching up. …Nf6 is still better for the reasons stated in Black's last move.
moves.6. Ng5: ? Too much! White cannot attack with just one Knight. Bc4 was just crying out to be played.
moves.6... Nf6: ? This developing move is too late. …Be7 is better, attacking the Knight and leaving the defensive move …Nh6 open.
moves.7. Nxf7: ?? This is the logical follow-up to White's play, but it just loses a piece. Again, you can't attack with just one piece! Bc4 was again obvious, natural and good. Black would have no good way to defend the f-pawn.
moves.7... Kxf7 8. Bc4+: Now this move comes… two moves too late.
moves.8... Ke8 9. Qb3: Where is White's attack? Black has the extra material AND the lead in development.
moves.9... exd4: ! Good, clearing some tension in the center to reduce complications.
moves.10... Ke7 11. Bg5: Finally getting some more pieces involved.
moves.13... Ne5: !? A very tricky way to defend, giving back a single pawn to exchange off White's last aggressive piece. Good eye!
moves.15. Bxc4 Nxc4 16. Qxc4 Rc8 17. Qe2: Now it is Black who attacks. I like how you didn't get stuck in defensive mode and seized your chance to end it quickly.
moves.17... Rc1+: ! Things don't look good for White…
moves.18. Kd2 Rxh1 19. e5: ! White seizes on every chance for counterplay, but it's not enough.
moves.19... Qa5+: ! Rather than defending, Black wraps things up with a nice attack before anything strange can happen on the e-file.
moves.20. Kd3: The worst of a set of bad options.
moves.20... Bb5+: ! No way Black was letting that one go. Excellent counterattacking.
